awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE:GeoVisuals Software: Capturing, Managing, and Utilizing GeoSpatial Multimedia Data for Collaborative Field Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Videos, photos, and narratives (audio, text, graphics) enriched with geospatial coordinates can be used to capture spatial data and associated contextual information for a variety of challenging environments. These data can fill gaps where no data exists, capture ephemeral or constantly changing information, and provide contextual insights that elevate local knowledge beyond more traditional methods. Example applications might include how a slum in Haiti changes after a vaccination intervention following a cholera outbreak, or identifying patterns of homeless camps (and their temporal stability) in Los Angeles. The GeoVisuals software system and a Web-based GeoVisuals Data Repository bridge the gap between the diversity of researcher needs and data infrastructure challenges often encountered "in the field". The computing infrastructures help domain researchers and decision-makers capture, manage, query and visualize such big, dynamic data to conduct exploratory and analytical tasks. The utilization of the tools spans across disciplines as diverse as anthropology, clinical health, criminology, disaster management, epidemiology, geography, planning, and sociology. GeoVisuals is being developed with collaboration from many domain researchers in academia, various branches of government, and non-profit sectors, and funded by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure and the Directorate of Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE). It is shared to users as public-licensed software with free access.

The GeoVisuals software consists of a mobile data collection module, a data transmission module, a data storage and computing module, and a visual analytics module. The software helps users to: (1) Capture and transfer geospatial multimedia data in a variety of different field settings ranging from developed countries with advanced IT infrastructures, to countries that still lack a reliable access to the Internet; (2) Manage and explore the collected data, when the data scale and dimensions impose technical challenges for non-IT professionals. It allows for the easy merging and query of GPS, video, audio, narratives, and so on - with flexibility for multiple input types; (3) Apply qualitative, quantitative, and spatial data analysis with mining algorithms, visual representations, and interactions. This robust and easy-to-use software enables the users to conduct information foraging and sense making on geospatial multimedia data. The GeoVisuals Data Repository allows field researchers to share their own data and access the analytical and visualization functions through a web-based platform, being inspired by the open access GenBank for biomedical researchers. The software and the data repository advance the research activities and grant applications of worldwide researchers and educators related to field studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
GeoVisuals is a software system which has been developed to fully leverage different forms of geographically enriched media, including videos, photos, and narratives (which comprise of audio, text, graphics). In so doing it allows different disciplines to collect, combine, analyze and display data in previously unavailable ways to gain fresh perspectives on some of the most challenging social problems. It helps domain researchers and decision-makers capture, manage, query and visualize videos, photos, and narratives (audio, text, graphics) enriched with geospatial coordinates. It provides a new platform spanning across many disciplines for domain researchers to directly utilize the big, dynamic geospatial visual datasets to conduct exploratory and analytical tasks.

Intellectual Merit:

GeoVisuals software supports researchers in a variety of environments to be in control of their own data, from collection through visualization and analysis. The software consists of a mobile data collection module (allowing for the creation of new relevant data), a data transmission module (enhancing collaborative work), a data storage and computing module (allowing for the merging of data geographically in the search to answer new questions), and a visual analytics module (to promote spatial visual exploration and result presentation). The software has been designed for all environments, allowing users  to: (1) Capture and transfer geospatial multimedia data irrespective of the local IT constraints, meaning GeoVisuals also works in locations with unreliable internet connectivity; (2) Manage and explore the collected data in a skill-free environment, meaning that collaborative teams can focus on their topical specialties, and what the data reveal, rather than being constrained by technical skillset availability. Likewise GeoVisuals allows for the easy input, merging and query of multiple media and data types, such as GPS paths, video, audio, narratives; (3) GeoVisuals provides spatial data analysis, visualization, and interactive querying tools to fully leverage insights from the combined data.

Broader Impacts:

Many forms of traditional "official" data provide only simple spatial and / or temporal insights into a problem. Far more can be gained by adding context, either through developing ways to more fully explore existing data, or by adding in new media, such as interviews or video, which can help tell the story behind an event. While tools that can help collect data, such as GPS enabled video cameras, have continued to develop, the software needed to fully combine, explore, and gain insight from these data has lagged behind. This means that researchers, officials, or activists in various settings may have the desire to collect enhanced data, but their ability to work with what they have collected is limited. This deficiency is true whether working in a small rural town in the United States, or overseas in challenging data poor environments. GeoVisuals helps break down these barriers by providing easy-to-use tools that can adapt to any field environment and the data challenges it poses. This means that interventions typically available for more data rich communities can now translate to those places with the most need. More than this, GeoVisuals also offers the opportunity for more data rich places to gain more nuanced context enriched insights. The spillover benefit of such a participatory model is that detailed data "stories" are collected that can also be used in classrooms.


Last Modified: 09/19/2021
Modified by: Ye Zhao
